question: In the narrative, how do the familial and mentorship connections—specifically, Cousin Cæsar Simon receiving his first lesson of reward for imagination from big-sis, who also raised him as the son of S. S. Simon's brother—impact the development of Cæsar Simon's character and his later relationships and actions within the interconnected Simon, Carlo, and Fairfield families?
gold_answer: Cousin Cæsar receives his first lesson of reward for imagination from big-sis, who also raises Cæsar Simon. This mentorship and familial link set the foundation for Cæsar Simon's later interactions, including his involvement in delivering important information and being part of a broader network that influences events among the Simon, Carlo, and Fairfield families.
llm_answer:
The single formative moment—when “big-sis,” the penniless washer-woman who is raising him, cuts her last loaf and spreads her last mouthful of butter on it and gives it to the dreaming child because he has said he “expected to see one of them bubbles burst into a l-o-a-f of b-r-e-a-d”—teaches Cousin Cæsar that an act of imagination can be instantly rewarded by someone who loves him. That lesson, delivered by the woman who is both foster-mother and only family, becomes the emotional template for the rest of his life: the world ought to give him what he pictures, and someone ought to pay the cost.

Because big-sis is the sister of S. S. Simon’s brother, Cæsar is born into the Simon bloodline but outside its wealth. The early indulgence from big-sis lets him grow up “too big to whip,” convinced that work is unnecessary and that someone will always rescue or feed him. When he later learns that his uncle S. S. Simon has left “one of the largest estates in Arkansas,” the childhood equation—imagination equals reward—turns into the conviction that the fortune is already his by right. The same certainty makes him detest the idea that the estate might pass to Roxie Fairfield (Roxie Daymon’s daughter), whom he regards as a “stranger.”

Thus the earliest bond with big-sis, who raised him as the orphaned son of the Simon brother, hard-wires an expectation of unearned abundance; every later relationship—his servile loyalty to Governor Mo-rock, his readiness to “break the will,” his shock at meeting Roxie Daymon’s daughter—flows from that first lesson that the world must rise to meet his visions.

Young Simon grew up without being inured to any hardships, and his health was not good, for he soon followed his father; during his short life he had everything that heart could desire, except a family name and good health, the lack of which made him almost as poor as the meanest of his slaves. Young Simon received some comfort in his last days from his cousin Cæsar. Cæsar Simon was the son of the brother of S. S. Simon who died in early life, leaving three children in West Tennessee. Cousin Cæsar was raised by two penniless sisters, whom he always called “big-sis” and “little-sis.” “Big-sis” was so called from being the eldest, and had the care of cousin Cæsar's childhood. Cousin Cæsar manifested an imaginary turn of mind in early childhood. He was, one day, sitting on his little stool, by the side of the tub in which “big-sis” was washing, (for she was a washer-woman,) gazing intently upon the surface of the water. “What in the world are you looking at C-a-e-s-a-r?” said the woman, straightening up in astonishment. “Looking at them bubbles on the suds,” said the boy,

And thus he received his first lesson of reward for imagination which, perhaps, had something to do with his after life. Cousin Cæsar detested work, but had a disposition to see the bottom of everything. No turkey-hen or guinea fowl could make a nest that cousin Cæsar could not find. He grew up mischievous, so much so that “big-sis” would occasionally thrash him. He would then run off and live with “little-sis” until “little-sis” would better the instruction, for she would whip also. He would then run back to live with “big-sis.” In this way cousin Cæsar grew to thirteen years of age--too big to whip. Simon hallooed _fair play_, and Brindle Bill _pitched in_. Brindle Bill was the stoutest man, Don Carlo the most active, the contest was sharp, and very doubtful, notwithstanding the boasting character of Brindle Bill, true pluck was upon the side of Don Carlo. At this critical moment, Simon's wife appeared upon the scene of action, the door of the cabin was fast, Simon was on the inside. She could hear the blows and smell the blood, for a lucky lick from Don had started the blood from Brindle Bill's nose, but could not see or know the combatants. Quick as thought, she applied the fire-brand to the cane pile, on the west end of the cabin. A strong breeze from the west soon enveloped the roof of the cabin in flames. The men rushed out into the open air much frightened. Simon's wife grabbed her husband and dragged him toward their home, with loud and eloquent cries of _shame_.
